case_name: Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 928 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 928 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 14, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 57 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 14, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 57 of 959.

facts.text: Phool Chand instituted a suit against the Union of India in the Court of the Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: One Phool Chand, the predecessor-in-title of the appellant Sawai Singhai Nirmal Chand, instituted a suit against the respondent, the Union of India, in the Court of the Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur,

facts.text: Phool Chand obtained a decree on 25-4-1951 for Rs. 24,234-14-0 and proportionate costs with interest 4 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: and obtained a decree on 25-4-1951 for Rs. 24,234-14-0 and proportionate costs with interest 4 per annum.

facts.text: The respondent challenged the decree by preferring an appeal in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the said decree by preferring an appeal in the High Court.

facts.text: Pending the appeal, the respondent deposited the decretal amount of Rs. 31,849-9-9.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal, the respondent deposited the decretal amount of Rs. 31.849-9-9.

facts.text: On December 14, 1952, Phool Chand withdrew Rs. 28,032-12-0 out of the said amount after furnishing due security.

anchor.surface_text: On December 14, 1952, phool Chand withdrew Rs. 28.032-12-0 out of the said amount after furnishing due security in that behalf.

facts.text: The respondent's appeal was partly allowed on June 26, 1954, and the decretal amount was reduced to Rs. 10,971-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the respondents appeal was partly allowed on June 26, 1954, and the decretal amount was reduced to Rs. 10,971-15-6.

facts.text: Phool Chand had withdrawn Rs. 15,340-14-8 in excess of his legitimate dues.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the total decretal amount due to the decree- holder Phool Chand came to Rs. 12,691-13-6 and that meant that he had withdrawn Rs. 15,340-14-8 in excess of his legitimate dues.

facts.text: On September 4, 1954, the respondent applied for restitution of the said amount and claimed interest thereon.

anchor.surface_text: On September 4. 1954, the respondent applied for restitution of the said amount and claimed interest thereon.

facts.text: The Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, allowed the said application.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Additional District Judge, Jabalpur, allowed the said application, and in execution of it,

facts.text: The respondent sought recovery by attachment and sale of certain immovable properties of Phool Chand.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent sought for the recovery of the said amount by attachment and sale of certain immovable properties of Phool Chand, mentioned in the application.

facts.text: The properties were sold by Phool Chand to the appellant by a registered sale deed executed on January 9, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: But, meanwhile, they had been sold by Phool Chand to the appellant by a registered sale deed executed on January 9, 1953.

facts.text: The appellant objected to the attachment under O.21 r. 58 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: That is why the appellant objected to the said attachment under O.21 r. 58 of the Code.

facts.text: The appellant's objection was over-ruled and his application was dismissed by the Second Additional District Judge on April 16, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: but his objection was over-ruled and his application was dismissed by the Second Additional District Judge on April 16, 1957.

facts.text: The appellant filed the present suit on June 23, 1958 in the Court of the First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: Before the appellant filed the present suit on June 23,1958 in the Court of the First Additional District Judge, Jabalpur,

facts.text: The appellant gave notice to the respondent under s. 80 of the Code on April 12, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: he gave notice to the respondent under s. 80 of the Code on April, 12, 1958.

facts.text: In the suit, the appellant claimed a declaration that the properties could not be attached and sold as title vested in him by valid sale deed.

anchor.surface_text: In the said suit, he claimed a declaration that the properties in question could not be attached and sold inasmuch as the title in respect of the said properties vested in him by virtue of a valid sale deed executed in his favour by Phool Chand.

facts.text: The respondent raised a plea of limitation in defence.

anchor.surface_text: In defence, the respondent raised a plea of limitation.

facts.text: It is common ground that the period of limitation for suit under O.21 r.63 is one year from the date of the order by Article 11 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the period of limitation prescribed for a suit under O. 21 r. 63 by Article 11 of the Limitation Act is one year from the date of the order under O. 21. r.

facts.text: The learned trial Judge and the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dismissed the suit as barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned trial Judge and the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, Jabalpur, have answered this question against the appellant, and the suit has, therefore, been dismissed as barred by time.

facts.text: The appellant came to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision that the appellant has come to this Court with a certificate granted by the said High Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: a suit filed under s. 283 (corresponding to O. 21 r. 63) is a continuation of attachment proceedings and treated as a form of appeal to set aside a summary decision

precedents.case_name: Amar Nath Dogra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: notice under s.80 given before first suit satisfies requirements for subsequent suit on same cause of action; purpose of notice is to give intimation to government of the claim
